article_content:
# ‘Pay Our Troops Act’ Referred to [Appropriations Committee](https://api.congress.gov/v3/committee/house/hsap00)

**Washington D.C.** – Legislation aimed at bolstering support for U.S. military personnel, officially titled the “Pay Our Troops Act of 2026” ([HR5401](https://www.congress.gov/bill/119th-congress/hr-bill/5401)), has been referred to the House Committee on Appropriations, according to recent data. The bill currently boasts 196 cosponsors.

Representative Jennifer A. Kiggans ([R-VA-2]) is a sponsor of [HR5401](https://www.congress.gov/bill/119th-congress/hr-bill/5401) and also serves as a member of the House Committee on Appropriations.  The bill was initially referred to the committee on September 16, 2025.

As of today, there have been no recorded hearings or proposed amendments for this legislation. The latest action documented is the referral itself. Notably, no votes have yet been scheduled or taken regarding [HR5401](https://www.congress.gov/bill/119th-congress/hr-bill/5401).  The bill falls under the broader policy area of Armed Forces and National Security.

## ‘One Big Beautiful Bill’ Becomes Public Law After Lengthy Congressional Process

**Washington D.C.** – [HR1](https://www.congress.gov/bill/119th-congress/hr-bill/1), officially known as the “One Big Beautiful Bill Act,” has been signed into law after a protracted period of debate and amendment within Congress. As of October 9, 2025, the bill has become Public Law No. 119-21, marking its official passage through both the House and Senate.

The legislation encompasses a wide range of policy changes, including significant tax cuts for individuals and corporations, measures aimed at reducing the national debt through spending caps and rescissions, and provisions impacting energy production and environmental regulations.  Changes to social programs like SNAP (Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program) are also included within the package. 

Rep. Jodey Arrington (R-TX-19) is credited as the bill’s sponsor, with it currently referred to the House [Budget Committee](https://api.congress.gov/v3/committee/house/hsbu00). Throughout its journey through Congress, the bill faced numerous amendments. Notably, Amendment SA 2848, aimed at improving the overall legislation, was agreed upon in the Senate, while Amendments SA 2849 and 2847 failed to gain approval by a narrow margin.  Numerous smaller “Smaller Amendatory Technical Changes” (SAMDTs) were also proposed.

The bill’s passage wasn't without significant budgetary scrutiny. The House [Budget Committee](https://api.congress.gov/v3/committee/house/hsbu00) held hearings and produced committee reports, including "H. Rept. 119-106, Book 1" and "H. Rept. 119-106, Book 2," which detailed the estimated impact on the deficit.  The Congressional Budget Office (CBO) repeatedly analyzed the bill’s budgetary effects, concluding that it would increase the deficit relative to various baseline budgets.

Votes were held on several amendments in the Senate on July 1, 2025; Amendment SA 2848 passed with a 51-50 vote (bipartisan), while Amendments SA 2849 and 2847 failed by votes of 45-55 and 50-50 respectively. The original bill itself was passed by the House on May 22, 2025.  Further details regarding the specific amendments and CBO analyses can be found in the referenced committee reports.

# House Bill [HR5371](https://www.congress.gov/bill/119th-congress/hr-bill/5371) Faces Senate Reconsideration

**Washington D.C.** – House Bill 5371, officially titled the “Continuing Appropriations and Extensions Act, 2026,” is currently navigating a complex process within Congress after receiving attention in the Senate. As of October 23, 2025, the bill has been referred to both the House [Appropriations Committee](https://api.congress.gov/v3/committee/house/hsap00) and the [Budget Committee](https://api.congress.gov/v3/committee/house/hsbu00), where Representative Tom Cole (R-OK-4) serves as a sponsor and is assigned to both committees.

The bill aims to provide continuing appropriations and extensions. Initial action included referrals to the Appropriations and [Budget Committee](https://api.congress.gov/v3/committee/house/hsbu00)s on September 16, 2025. Subsequently, Senator Mike Thune moved to reconsider the vote regarding cloture – a procedural motion intended to potentially stall or alter the consideration process – on [HR5371](https://www.congress.gov/bill/119th-congress/hr-bill/5371). This motion was recorded as Record Vote No. 581 in the Senate.

According to available data, votes have already been held on the bill.  However, information regarding the outcome of these votes, specifically whether they were party-line or bipartisan, is not currently accessible. Furthermore, details surrounding any proposed amendments, including Senator Thune’s motion, remain undisclosed at this time. 

Currently, [HR5371](https://www.congress.gov/bill/119th-congress/hr-bill/5371) awaits further consideration within the House committees before potentially moving to a full vote in the House.

bill_title: National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2026
article_content:
## Senate Passes National Defense Authorization Act with Key Amendments

**Washington D.C.** – The Senate passed the “National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2026” ([S2296](https://www.congress.gov/bill/119th-congress/s-bill/2296)) on October 9, 2025, in a bipartisan vote of 77-20 (Record Vote Number: 570). Sponsored by Senator Roger Wicker (R-MS), the bill authorizes defense spending and includes several significant amendments, known as Senate Amendments (SAMDTs).

The legislation underwent a thorough review process, with a hearing held by the Senate [Armed Services Committee](https://api.congress.gov/v3/committee/senate/ssas00) on July 16, 2025, which resulted in the committee reporting the original measure.  Several amendments were proposed throughout the bill’s consideration, all submitted as SAMDTs. 

Notably, Amendment SA 3928, also sponsored by Senator Wicker, mandates the establishment of a pilot program for deploying microreactors within the Department of Defense. This amendment was approved via voice vote on October 9th.  However, Amendment SA 3927, aimed at limiting the use of Federal law enforcement officers for crowd control, failed to pass with a Yea-Nay vote of 47-50 on the same date.

Furthermore, Amendment SA 3926, focused on national security and sanctions against specific individuals within the People’s Republic of China, was also adopted by voice vote.  Senator Wicker has proposed numerous additional amendments – SA 3925 through 3915 – which cover a range of national security and defense policy matters.

The bill's passage represents a significant step in shaping the nation’s defense strategy for the upcoming fiscal year. Further action will likely be taken as the legislation moves through the House of Representatives.

bill_title: A bill to designate the facility of the United States Postal Service located at 154 First Avenue East in Jerome, Idaho, as the "Representative Maxine Bell Post Office".
article_content:
# Idaho Post Office Designated with Senate Bill 24

**Jerome, ID –** A United States Postal Service facility in Jerome, Idaho, is slated for designation as the “Representative Maxine Bell Post Office” following the introduction of Senate Bill 24. The bill has undergone two readings and was recently referred to the Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs.

Senator Mike Crapo (R-ID) is a key sponsor of the legislation and also serves as a member of that same committee, indicating its initial progress within the legislative process.  As of today, no amendments have been proposed for Senate Bill 24.

Currently, the bill remains within the [Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Committee](https://api.congress.gov/v3/committee/senate/ssga00) for consideration. However, data indicates that no hearings related to the legislation have yet been scheduled, and there is no information available regarding votes or whether the discussion will be along party lines. The bill’s path forward at this time is primarily focused on committee review.

bill_title: Continuing Appropriations and Extensions and Other Matters Act, 2026
article_content:
# Senate Considers Continuing Resolution [S2882](https://www.congress.gov/bill/119th-congress/s-bill/2882) Amidst Debate

**Washington, D.C.** – Senator Patty Murray (D-WA) introduced the “Continuing Appropriations and Extensions and Other Matters Act, 2026,” identified as bill [S2882](https://www.congress.gov/bill/119th-congress/s-bill/2882), aiming to provide continued funding for various government agencies through 2026. As of October 9, 2025, the bill is currently under consideration in the Senate with a motion to reconsider filed.

According to data available on the bill’s status, no hearings have been scheduled and no committees have yet taken action on [S2882](https://www.congress.gov/bill/119th-congress/s-bill/2882).  Furthermore, no amendments have been proposed at this time. Recent activity includes a motion by Senator Schumer to reconsider a vote regarding a cloture motion – indicating ongoing debate and potentially differing viewpoints within the Senate regarding the bill’s provisions.

The bill currently has no listed committees associated with it, and does not include any co-sponsors according to available information.  It represents a continuing resolution designed to extend funding for government agencies through 2026.

# Senate Bill Aims to Prevent Future Government Shutdowns

**Washington D.C.** – Senator Rand Paul (R-KY) has introduced the “Government Shutdown Prevention Act of 2025,” a measure currently under review by the Senate Committee on Appropriations. The bill, designated as Senate Bill 499, was read twice and subsequently referred to the committee earlier this week.

According to available data, the bill falls within the policy area of Economics and Public Finance. As of today, no hearings have been scheduled regarding the legislation, and no amendments have been proposed.  The most recent action documented for the bill is its referral to the [Appropriations Committee](https://api.congress.gov/v3/committee/senate/ssap00) – a step required before further consideration can proceed. 

Senator Paul is the sole sponsor of the bill at this time; information on any co-sponsors has not yet been released. No votes have occurred, and there are currently no indications of a timeline for further action beyond committee review.

bill_title: An executive resolution authorizing the en bloc consideration in Executive Session of certain nominations on the Executive Calendar.
article_content:
# Senate Passes Executive Resolution Authorizing Nominations Without Amendment

**Washington D.C.** – The U.S. Senate passed an executive resolution, [S.Res. 412](https://www.congress.gov/bill/119th-congress/sres-bill/412), authorizing the en bloc consideration of certain nominations on the Executive Calendar on October 3, 2025, with a vote of 51-46. Senator John Thune (R-SD) is the sole sponsor of the bill.

According to data provided, the resolution was agreed to without amendment and is currently in its final stages of passage.  Notably, the bill has no associated committees listed and does not include information regarding cosponsors. 

Furthermore, two amendments were proposed for [S.Res. 412](https://www.congress.gov/bill/119th-congress/sres-bill/412) by Senator Thune – amendments numbered 3918 and 3919, both classified as Senate Amendments in the Form of a Manager’s Amendment (SAMDTs). This indicates a bipartisan effort within the chamber, with 51 senators voting in favor and 46 opposing.  No hearings have been scheduled or reported on for this resolution.

bill_title: Impeaching Donald John Trump, President of the United States, for high crimes and misdemeanors.
article_content:
# House Resolution 353 Seeks Impeachment of Trump; Pending Judiciary Review

**Washington D.C.** – House Resolution 353, an effort to impeach former U.S. President Donald John Trump for high crimes and misdemeanors, is currently under review by the House [Judiciary Committee](https://api.congress.gov/v3/committee/house/hsju00). The resolution was sponsored by Representative Shri Thanedar (D-MI-13) and as of May 16, 2025, has been referred to the committee.

According to available data, the bill’s referral to the [Judiciary Committee](https://api.congress.gov/v3/committee/house/hsju00) took place on April 28, 2025, with a “Referred To” designation indicating initial action.  Representative Thanedar is also listed as a cosponsor and sits on the [Judiciary Committee](https://api.congress.gov/v3/committee/house/hsju00) itself. There is one other cosponsor, though one withdrew from the effort.

Crucially, no amendments have been proposed for HRES 353 at this time. The bill’s JSON data indicates an empty list of proposed amendments.  As of today, no votes have been held regarding the resolution; the most recent activity documented involves notification of intent to offer a resolution – a preliminary step before any formal vote would occur. 

The status of HRES 353 remains pending within the [Judiciary Committee](https://api.congress.gov/v3/committee/house/hsju00) as they evaluate the proposal for consideration.

bill_title: Full-Year Continuing Appropriations and Extensions Act, 2025
article_content:
## House Bill 1968 Passes as Public Law, Includes Key Amendments

**Washington D.C.** – The “Full-Year Continuing Appropriations and Extensions Act, 2025” ([HR1968](https://www.congress.gov/bill/119th-congress/hr-bill/1968)) has officially become Public Law No. 119-4, marking its passage through the U.S. House of Representatives and subsequent action by Congress.  The bill, which provides continuing appropriations for fiscal year 2025 and extends certain authorizations, was referred to both the [Appropriations Committee](https://api.congress.gov/v3/committee/house/hsap00) (hsap00) and the [Budget Committee](https://api.congress.gov/v3/committee/house/hsbu00) (hsbu00) earlier in its process.

Sponsored by Representative Tom Cole (R-OK-4), [HR1968](https://www.congress.gov/bill/119th-congress/hr-bill/1968) includes several amendments addressing key policy areas.  Multiple hearings were held on the bill, with the Committee on Rules holding a hearing on March 10th, 2025, and the Committee on Appropriations conducting a hearing on March 11th, 2025.

Key among these amendments are the “HAMDT Amendment (H.Amdt. 8),” also proposed by Cole, which relates to a rules amendment A001.  Additionally, Representative Cole introduced several other amendments known as SAMDTs – specifically Amendments 1274, 1273, 1272, 1271, 1270, and 1269 – all aimed at addressing issues such as veteran federal employee reinstatement, rescissions, and the use of Department of Defense (DOGE) funds.  However, these SAMDTs failed to gain sufficient support in the Senate, falling short of the required majority vote.

As of March 15th, 2025, amendments SA 1274, 1273, and 1272 were defeated in the Senate with vote margins of 47-53.  Analysis suggests a significant partisan divide on these specific provisions, though detailed voting records are limited.

Notably, Representative Cole is not currently a member of either the Appropriations or [Budget Committee](https://api.congress.gov/v3/committee/house/hsbu00)s. The bill's journey to becoming Public Law No. 119-4 involved passage through both chambers of Congress, solidifying its place in federal legislation for the current fiscal year.
